docs.snippet: The Syrian army backed by Russian air strikes is aiming to capture the historic city of Palmyra from Islamic State to open a road to the eastern province of Deir al-Zor in an offensive that got under way this week, a source close to the Syrian...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Syrian army backed by Russian air strikes is aiming to capture the historic city of Palmyra from Islamic State to open a road to the eastern province of Deir al-Zor in an offensive that got under way this week, a source close to the Syrian government said.

headline.main: Syrian Army Aims for Eastward Advance With Palmyra Attack
headline.print_headline: Syrian Army Aims for Eastward Advance With Palmyra Attack

docs.snippet: Replacing potentially lethal Takata Corp air bags in a mass recall is more challenging and time-consuming than expected as rival parts suppliers struggle to make bag inflators that replicate the originals fitted by the Japanese firm.
docs.lead_paragraph: Replacing potentially lethal Takata Corp air bags in a mass recall is more challenging and time-consuming than expected as rival parts suppliers struggle to make bag inflators that replicate the originals fitted by the Japanese firm.

headline.main: 'Hamburgers',' Hotdogs' and How Air Bag Rivals Are Struggling to Displace Takata
headline.print_headline: 'Hamburgers',' Hotdogs' and How Air Bag Rivals Are Struggling to Displace Takata

docs.snippet: Former first lady Nancy Reagan will be buried at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, next to her husband.

docs.snippet: Oil prices might have bottomed as production declines in the United States and other non-OPEC producers accelerate and an increase in Iranian supply has been less than dramatic, the International Energy Agency said on Friday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Oil prices might have bottomed as production declines in the United States and other non-OPEC producers accelerate and an increase in Iranian supply has been less than dramatic, the International Energy Agency said on Friday.

headline.main: IEA Says Oil May Have Bottomed as Non-OPEC Producers Cut Output
headline.print_headline: IEA Says Oil May Have Bottomed as Non-OPEC Producers Cut Output

docs.snippet: Oil rose up to 2 percent on Friday, with U.S. crude gaining for a fourth straight week, after the world's energy watchdog said the market may have hit bottom, although Goldman Sachs said the 50 percent rally in under two months was "premature."
docs.lead_paragraph: Oil rose up to 2 percent on Friday, with U.S. crude gaining for a fourth straight week, after the world's energy watchdog said the market may have hit bottom, although Goldman Sachs said the 50 percent rally in under two months was "premature."

headline.main: Oil Up as IEA Sees Tighter Supply; Goldman Says Rally Premature
headline.print_headline: Oil Up as IEA Sees Tighter Supply; Goldman Says Rally Premature

docs.snippet: The first delivery of Russia's S-300 missile defence system to Iran will take place in August or September this year, RIA news agency on Friday quoted Sergei Chemezov, the head of Russia's industrial conglomerate Rostec, as saying.
docs.lead_paragraph: The first delivery of Russia's S-300 missile defence system to Iran will take place in August or September this year, RIA news agency on Friday quoted Sergei Chemezov, the head of Russia's industrial conglomerate Rostec, as saying.

headline.main: Russia to Ship First S-300 Missile System to Iran in August-September-RIA Cites Official

docs.snippet: Nestlé USA is voluntarily recalling a limited number of DiGiorno, Lean Cuisine and Stouffer’s products.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nestlé USA is voluntarily recalling a limited number of DiGiorno, Lean Cuisine and Stouffer’s products.
docs.abstract: Nestle USA is voluntarily recalling some DiGiorno, Lean Cuisine and Stouffer's products because they may contain small pieces of glass.

headline.main: Fearing Glass Contamination, Nestlé Issues a Limited Recall
headline.print_headline: Fearing Glass Contamination, Nestlé Issues a Limited Recall

docs.snippet: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.
docs.abstract: Justice Dept, in new court filing, argues that not even company as large as Apple can be allowed to defy law by refusing to help Federal Bureau of Investigation unlock iPhone used by San Bernardino gunman; Apple reacts with anger and emotional rebuke to what it says is brief laden with false accusations of company's intent.

headline.main: Apple and U.S. Bitterly Turn Up Volume in iPhone Privacy Fight
headline.print_headline: Apple’s Fight With U.S. Turns Up the Volume

byline.contributor: Eric Lichtblau reported from Washington and Katie Benner from San Francisco.
byline.original: By ERIC LICHTBLAU and KATIE BENNER

docs.snippet: Several title teams, which failed to secure automatic berths in the tournament through conference postseason play, now need invitations from the selection committee.

docs.abstract: Several men's college basketball title teams fail to secure automatic NCAA tournament berths through conference postseason play and now need invitations from selection committee.

headline.main: Monmouth and Other Midmajor Champions Find Themselves on the N.C.A.A. Bubble
headline.print_headline: Midmajor Champions Are Crowding the Bubble

docs.snippet: Friday marks the fifth anniversary of the powerful earthquake and subsequent tsunami that hit Japan, swallowing coastal villages, leaving more than 18,000 people dead or missing and devastating large swaths of the country's northeastern coastal area....
docs.lead_paragraph: Friday marks the fifth anniversary of the powerful earthquake and subsequent tsunami that hit Japan, swallowing coastal villages, leaving more than 18,000 people dead or missing and devastating large swaths of the country's northeastern coastal area. Some places are still unlivable and require massive reconstruction to restore infrastructure, houses and people's lives. Here's a look, by the numbers, at the March 11, 2011, disaster:

headline.main: BY THE NUMBERS: Recovering From the Tsunami, 5 Years On
headline.print_headline: BY THE NUMBERS: Recovering From the Tsunami, 5 Years On
